caption:
Table 1: Two network architectures: CNN-6 (MNIST, FMNIST) 

and ResNet-110 (CIFAR-10,100 and SVHN). Features are ex-
tracted in CNN-6 (after Layer 3 and two FC layers) and ResNet-
110 (after Layer 3, 4 and FC layer) to impose the proposed LPC. 
Auxiliary branches are shown in green color.

Table 2: Robustness of our model in white-box and black-box settings. Adversarial samples generated in the black-box settings show 

negligible attack potential against our models. Here is the perturbation size and c is the initial constant for C&W attack. It can be seen 
that AdvTrain further complements the robustness of our models.
mergedAllColumns: using FGSM [ 10 ] and PGD [ 22 ] by uniformly sampling

associatedMergedColumns: using FGSM [ 10 ] and PGD [ 22 ] by uniformly sampling
using FGSM [ 10 ] and PGD [ 22 ] by uniformly sampling

caption:
Table 3: Robustness in adaptive white-box attack settings. The 

performance for conventional attacks (where CE is the adversarial 
loss) is shown in blue.  *  indicates adversarially trained models.

Table 4: Comparison on CIFAR-100 dataset for white-box adver-

sarial attacks (numbers shows robustness, higher is better).  *  sign 
denotes adversarially trained models. For our model, we report 
results without adversarial training (Ours) and with adversarially 
generated images from FGSM (Ours  *  
f ) and PGD (Ours  *  
p ) attacks.

Table 6: Transferability Test on CIFAR-10: PGD adversaries 

are generated with = 0.03, using the source network, and then 
evaluated on target model. Underline denotes robustness against 
white-box attack. Note that adversarial samples generated on our 
model are highly transferable to other models as black-box at-
tacked images.

Table 7: Ablation Analysis with LPC applied at different layers 

of ResNet-110 (Table 1) for CIFAR-10 dataset.

Table 8: Comparison on CIFAR-10 dataset for white-box adversarial attacks (numbers shows robustness, higher is better).  *  sign denotes 

adversarially trained models. For our model, we report results without adversarial training (Ours) and with adversarially generated images 
from FGSM (Ours  *  
f ) and PGD (Ours  *  
p ) attacks.

Table 9: Comparison on MNIST dataset for white-box adversarial attacks (numbers shows robustness, higher is better).  *  sign denotes 

adversarially trained models. For our model, we report results without adversarial training (Ours) and with adversarially generated images 
from FGSM (Ours  *  
f ) and PGD (Ours  *
